Resource package upgrade Upgrade If enabled, your personal information (profile picture, nickname, gender, age, height, weight, etc.) will be uploaded to the cloud server. If disabled, your personal information (profile picture, nickname, gender, age, height, weight, etc.) will be saved locally on the phone and will not be uploaded to the cloud server. If enabled, your exercise data (including device location, exercise route, exercise type, exercise duration, steps, distance, calories, pace, exercise heart rate, etc.) will be uploaded to the cloud server. If disabled, your exercise data (including device location, exercise route, exercise type, exercise duration, steps, distance, calories, pace, exercise heart rate, etc.) will be saved locally on the phone and will not be uploaded to the cloud server. If enabled, your health data (including heart rate, sleep, blood oxygen saturation, stress, menstrual cycle, etc.) will be uploaded to the cloud server. If disabled, your health data (including heart rate, sleep, blood oxygen saturation, stress, menstrual cycle, etc.) will be saved locally on the phone and will not be uploaded to the cloud server. Hand-washing reminder Blood oxygen saturation (SpO2) is a measurement of your blood’s oxygen-carrying capacity. It is the percentage of hemoglobin which is currently bound to oxygen in the blood that accounts for the total hemoglobin that can be bound to oxygen, i.e., the oxygen concentration in blood. It is a vital physiological parameter of the respiratory system. Ideally, a normal blood oxygen level is 95%-100%, but it may vary depending on the altitude, an individual\'s physical condition and certain diseases. Low blood oxygen levels may indicate certain risks: With this feature enabled, the device will automatically measure and record your blood oxygen level when it detects that you are in static state. Measurement results can assit you to observe your health status (for example, during sleep or when you are at high altitude). This feature will shorten your device’s standby time. Reminder period Default reply content Default reply OK Add reply Device is fully charged Device is not connected to phone Data not synchronized for %s days Exercise record is synchronized, tap to view Sleep record is synchronized, tap to view Real-time pace Fastest pace (real-time) Real-time stride cadence Altitude Min. altitude Max. altitude Cumulative fall Training effect Recovery training This training slightly improves your body recovery, which is very important for high-intensity training over the long term. A regular exerciser can start high intensity training again when he/she feels ready. Maintenance training This training continuously improves your cardiorespiratory endurance, which is good for your health. But its intensity does not meet the standard of high-intensity training, please keep going. Beginners should gradually progress to lay a solid foundation, while regular exercisers can do recovery training at this intensity. Improve training Please keep going! This training continuously improves your physical performance. Doing this training 2–4 times a week can help improve your cardiorespiratory fitness. High-efficiency training This training improves your physical performance. Please take recovery time into consideration when making your training plan so as to maintain your fitness level. Excessive training This training is too intense and causes adverse effects. It needs time for your body to recover. Please include rest and relaxation in your training to recover your body. Blood oxygen is a measurement of the amount of oxygen in the protein (hemoglobin) in your red blood cells. Scheduled Start using the new app icon now? About Exercises Definitions Cadence: the number of running steps per minute (reference goal: 180 steps/min). For runners with low cadence, a proper increase in cadence can help improve the performance and reduce the impact force the body receives when hitting the ground. The cadence can be improved through targeted training, such as running with small-step running or high-knee running.
The distance between the landing points of the two feet. The size of the stride mainly depend on the runner\'s posture, muscle strength and technical movements.
The stride can be improved through targeted training, such as step running,kicking, etc. Stroke: the number of strokes that are completed per unit time (per minute). SWOLF: an indirect measure of swim efficiency, namely the sum of time (in seconds) and stroke count to complete a given distance (SWOLF = Swim + Golf). A smaller SWOLF score indicates higher swimming efficiency. Blood pressure is the force of blood pushing against the walls of the arteries as your heart pumps blood. It includes two measurements. "Systolic" is your blood pressure when your heart beats while pumping blood.
"Diastolic" is your blood pressure when the heart is at rest between beats. You usually see blood pressure numbers written with the systolic number above or before the diastolic number (for example, 120/80). External factors (such as sleep position, low blood perfusion, excessive arm hair, tattoos, arm drooping, arm shaking, improper wearing of watch and low temperature, etc.) may lead to an inaccurate measurement, or even a measurement failure. The respiratory rate is the number of breaths you take per minute. One rise and one fall of the chest equals one breath. The act of breathing includes inhaling and exhaling. When you inhale, air enters your lungs, and oxygen from that air moves to your blood. When you exhale, carbon dioxide moves from your blood to your lungs and is expelled. battery as last month What is body battery? Body battery refers to the energy that can be used by the body. Battery is a virtual indicator that is comprehensively evaluated based on the human body\'s heart rate, activity, stress and sleep performance. It measures the recovery and consumption of physical strength and energy in a day. Body battery can help you understand the state of your body. When the value is high, it means that you have enough energy for work or exercise; on the contrary, when the value is low, it means that the body needs to rest and replenish energy. Sleep is the best way to recharge, and usually enough sleep time and higher sleep quality will replenish you with more battery. When working, studying, exercising, or feeling tired and anxious will consume the body\'s battery; It can also be recovered by taking short breaks or relax the mind and body, breathe training, and meditatrion also can recover the battery battery performance How to recover the battery: Behavior of battery consume Ways to slow down battery consumption: A single high-intensity exercise will obviously consume battery, but maintaining the amount of exercise for a long time can improve the body battery intensity, which will help reduce battery consumption and maintain more energy in the long run) 1. To monitor body battery, you need to turn on continuous heart rate as well, otherwise it cannot be detected. 3. This product is not a medical device. The data we provided for reference only and cannot be used as a basis for clinical diagnosis and treatment. Body battery detection "Body battery" tracking relies on continuous heart rate measurement. Body battery tracking will also be turned off when you turned off. Are you sure you want to turn it off? "Body battery" tracking relies on continuous heart rate measurement. Heart rate variability (HRV) is the length of time between heartbeats that varies from heart to heart. It contains information on the regulation of the cardiovascular system by neurohumoral factors, so as to judge the condition and prevention of cardiovascular and other diseases. To know Heart Rate Variability Heart rate variability (HRV) is the length of time between heartbeats that varies from heart to heart. Usually measured in milliseconds. The HRV is lower if the difference between two heartbeats is small, and a lower HRV means a higher risk of anxiety, depression morbidity, and cardiovascular mortality. On the contrary, the difference between the interval and the interval between two heartbeats is relatively large, then the HRV is relatively high. Generally speaking, people with higher HRV generally have better cardiovascular function and stress resistance. Everyday Learn About Sleep Stages Sleep stages include drowsiness, REM (rapid eye movement), light sleep and deep sleep. The time ratio of each stage can reflect the quality of sleep. Sleep Stages In general, you should wake up no more than twice at night. Even if you get up for bathroom, you should be able to fall asleep immediately after you lie down again. Frequent awakenings of more than 30min indicate symptoms of sleep disorder. During REM sleep, the brain activity accelerates, approaching the level in waking state. REM sleep is considered essential for cognitive functions such as memory, learning and creativity. Most dreams happen during REM sleep. The body enters a state of relaxation, with lower body temperature, muscle relaxation, slower breathing and lower HR. At the same time, the brain waves demonstrate a new pattern, the eye movement stops, and the brain activity slows down. The body relaxes further, and it is more difficult to wake up. This stage has the effects of eliminating fatigue, restoring energy, body growth, immunity and disease resistance, and consolidating memory. What is RHR? A good time to check RHR is in the morning after you’ve had a good night’s sleep, before you stand up and mover around. Generally, a lower heart rate at rest implies more efficient heart function and better cardiovascular fitness. You can lower your RHR by exercising regularly, managing body weight and relieving stress. RHR is not the heart rate in your sleep.
